Replying to @DinisCruz 2018-01-09 13:07
@DinisCruz @sec_tigger @Netlify Read access or admin access? I believe that Github API rather course-grained permissions mean that Netlify needs more than just read access. (it manages things like webhooks and deploy keys for you) More info here, https://t.co/xNIhVkbPH9 (or via support in the Netlify admin)

Replying to @_Nec 2018-01-08 15:38
@_Nec @Netlify If you have a package.json in the root of your repo, 'npm install' will run before each build (we cache the install result until package.json changes). But you can run different build commands depending on your your build context: https://t.co/15kyHEecfb

Replying to @ 2018-01-08 09:27
@DirtyF @Scott_Helme @troyhunt @Netlify You can configure any headers you like. Including your own custom headers. https://t.co/Re1E3LtmKh Keep in mind that Cache-Control headers will override Expires headers if you have both though. https://t.co/FU1wAXKJo2
  • Permalink
  • Twitter
Replying to @DinisCruz 2018-01-08 09:18
@DinisCruz You got it! You need to add a Gemfile to specify the version of Jekyll you want to build with. The post you linked to should get you there. @Netlify is agnostic of the SSG & build dependancies you choose. Rather than infer versions etc, we give you control to specify. All set?
